channel.title: Comments on: First look at SQL Server Management Studio Denali
channel.description: A Technical Community for IT Professionals

item.title: By: SQLDenis
item.dc:creator: SQLDenis
item.description: Carla, I know..I wrote these posts before Denali was released to the general public and back then it did not come with documentation
item.content:encoded: Carla, I know..I wrote these posts before Denali was released to the general public and back then it did not come with documentation

item.title: By: Carla Sabotta
item.dc:creator: Carla Sabotta
item.description: Documentation for Denali CTP1 is available on Books Online, at "<a href="http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/bb522534(SQL.110).aspx">What's New (Integration Services)</a>" and at<a href="http://social.technet.microsoft.com/wiki/contents/articles/sql-server-integration-services-ssis.aspx"> SQL Server Integration Services (SSIS)</a>
item.content:encoded: Documentation for Denali CTP1 is available on Books Online, at “What’s New (Integration Services)” and at SQL Server Integration Services (SSIS)

item.title: By: SQLDenis
item.dc:creator: SQLDenis
item.description: You can still do stuff the old way...remember when I wrote all this up there was no documentation available yet. I will take a better look at this in the coming weeks
item.content:encoded: You can still do stuff the old way…remember when I wrote all this up there was no documentation available yet. I will take a better look at this in the coming weeks

item.title: By: riverguy
item.dc:creator: riverguy
item.description: Are you saying that SSIS packages are not stored in MSDB but are instead stored in a user database? And that user database is created when you "create a catalog?" Does this also mean that SSIS is now an instanced service instead of a shared service over the whole server?
item.content:encoded: Are you saying that SSIS packages are not stored in MSDB but are instead stored in a user database? And that user database is created when you “create a catalog?” Does this also mean that SSIS is now an instanced service instead of a shared service over the whole server?
